title: 1.5 mill judgment against me from a car accident, make too much for chapter 7 (even w expenses), but owe too much for Chap 13?
question: I read that the unsecured debt limit for a chapter 13 is 354000 or close. What do you do if you owe more and need to file bankruptcy?
answers:
That judgment represents "non-consumer" debt so the "median income" test will not apply to you. You can file a Chapter 7 but if your disposable monthly income is too great, the Office of the US Trustee might attempt to force you into a Chapter 11. This has been permitted in other jurisdictions, although I'm not aware of any cases in our circuit.

Good luck!

Rob

How much money you make is only a factor if your debt is primarily consumer debt. 11 U.S.C. 707(b). If you need to file bankruptcy regardless, you might as well file Chapter 7 first, assert that your debt is not primarily consumer debt, and see if anyone objects. If your Chapter 7 is denied you can pursue your Chapter 11 options.

I don't know if a personal injury judgment is non-consumer or not. 11 U.S.C. (8) defines consumer debt but it is pretty vague. The cases I am aware of regarding consumer debt tend to focus on whether there was a "profit motive" in which case it is non-consumer debt.

If the only issue is that you make too much money, not that you have non-exempt assets, some creative strategy and planning may be helpful. I have seen debtors get discharges in Chapter 7 when they have been told by more than one attorney that they make too much money. They just needed to find an attorney willing to pursue a discharge for them when they had complicated facts.

Chapter 11 bankruptcies are not very common. However, there should be a few local attorneys who do them and know what you would be looking at as far as payments go. They are so different from Chapter 7 or 13 that I won't even advise my clients regarding what their payments might look like in Chapter 11.

Good luck.

It may be possible for you to file a Chapter 7 case if you can show that the majority (over 50%) of your debt is considered "non-consumer" debt. This is possible even if the amount of money you earn is over the income limits for a chapter 7. An experienced attorney in your area would need to analyze your debt to determine if you would qualify for a non-consumer Chapter 7, but given that the $1.5M judgment would likely be considered non-consumer debt, you very well could have a good case.

Attorney Fenn hit the nail right in the head. The unsecured debt limit is for consumer debt and I haven't reviewed the case law, doubt if your judgment qualifies as consumer debt.Be aware , however, if that car accident judgment against you is the result of driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, then that debt cannot be discharged in bankruptcy.
You will have to file a personal Chapter 11. Seek the advice of a local Chapter 11 bankruptcy attorney as Chapter 11 cases are tricky.
YOu have to consider filing either Chapter 7 or else if no possible Chapter 11.
